question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $Q$ be a polynomial \[Q(x)=a_0+a_1x+\cdots+a_nx^n,\]where $a_0,\ldots,a_n$ are nonnegative integers.  Given that $Q(1)=4$ and $Q(5)=152$, find $Q(6)$.
inference:
Let $P(x)=Q(x+1)$.  Then $P(x)$ is a polynomial with nonnegative integer coefficients: \[P(x)=b_0+b_1x+\cdots+b_nx^n\]where $b_i=a_i$.  In particular, $P(0)=Q(1)=4$ and $P(4)=Q(5)=152$.  Using the binomial theorem, we have \begin{align*}
P(4)&=b_0+4b_1+6b_2+4b_3+b_4\\
&=4+4b_1+6(b_2-b_1)+4(b_3-b_2)+b_4-b_3\\
&=4+4(b_1-b_2+b_3-b_4)+6(b_2-b_1)+b_4\\
&=4+4P(3)+6(P(2)-P(3))+P(4)\\
&=5P(3)+6P(2)-2P(4).
\end{align*}Thus, $11P(3)=6P(2)-3P(4)=6\cdot4-3\cdot152=-436$.  It follows that $P(3)=436/11=39.63636\ldots$, which is a contradiction.

Final Answer: \\boxed{$\text{None}$}. I hope it is correct.

question:
Let $P(x)=Q(x+1)$.  Then $P(x)$ is a polynomial with nonnegative integer coefficients: \[P(x)=b_0+b_1x+\cdots+b_nx^n\]where $b_i=a_i$.  In particular, $P(0)=Q(1)=4$ and $P(4)=Q(5)=152$.  Using the binomial theorem, we have \begin{align*}
P(4)&=b_0+4b_1+6b_2+4b_3+b_4\\
&=4+4b_1+6(b_2-b_1)+4(b_3-b_2)+b_4-b_3\\
&=4+4(b_1-b_2+b_3-b_4)+6(b_2-b_1)+b_4\\
&=4+4P(3)+6(P(2)-P(3))+P(4)\\
&=5P(3)+6P(2)-2P(4).
\end{align*}Thus, $11P(3)=6P(2)-3P(4)=6\cdot4-3\cdot152=-436$.  It follows that $P(3)=436/11=39.63636\ldots$, which is a contradiction.

Final Answer: \\boxed{$\text{None}$}. I hope it is correct.
